snippet: The rise of the Socialist François Hollande, who is slightly favored to win the French presidency on Sunday, is still a surprise to many in the country.
abstract: Rise of the French Socialist Party candidate Francois Hollande, who is slightly favored to win France's presidential election, is still a surprise to many in the country who see him as a hardworking and convivial but second-rank politician. Photo (M)5
lead_paragraph: PARIS -- François Hollande, the 57-year-old favored to be elected narrowly on Sunday as France's president, is no revolutionary. He likes to talk of ''harmony'' and ''pragmatism'' and often quotes the poet and politician Aimé Césaire about ''lucid hope.'' With a father on the far right and a social-worker mother, Mr. Hollande grew up on the edge of the 1968 protests that nearly overthrew the French government. They shocked him, but also politicized him, he said in a recent interview, making him understand that change was possible even in the France of Charles de Gaulle.

headline.main: In Race to French Presidency, the Tortoise Sets His Own Pace
